page.title: 05Cheese Farming
page.content: The cheese farm at West Town House receives 10000 litres of milk daily from their own and other local farms. They employ four people. The milk is stored in five tanks leading into the pasturiser. Rennet is added to turn the milk to curds and whey. The curd is cut into small pieces by a machine, being restacked and turned until all the whey is sqeezed out. Salt is added to help preserve the cheese which is packed in cloth-lined moulds. These Cheddar cheeses, which are approximately 40 pounds each in weight, are pressed for twenty-four hours and then stored in wooden boxes in a cold room. As well as 300 pounds of butter, 250 tons of cheese is produced each year. Some is sold locally but most is sold to the Cheese Marketing Board.
